title: Bus operator in outback New South Wales sells to national bus company
text:
By Sofie Wainwright and Rebekah Lowe Updated December 01, 2016 18:58:27 Map: Broken Hill 2880 
A bus operator that has been servicing the isolated city of Broken Hill in far west New South Wales for more than 80 years is selling to a nationally-operated private bus company. 
The Murtons bus brand has been operating in Broken Hill since 1935, when several bus companies merged and formed the Murton Street bus syndicate. 
Buses have been an important form of transport for residents ever since the many bus operators ran replacement services when the steam tramway system closed in 1926. 
The company has changed names and hands over the decades, and has been operating as Murton's Citybus since 1997, providing town and school services in Broken Hill and picking up passengers at Wilcannia and Menindee. Photo: Coaches were part of the Murtons fleet in the 1980s and early 1990s. (Murton's Citybus) 
Tim Williams is an accredited manager and director of Murtons and has been with the company since 1985. 
Mr Williams said it was sad to let go but it was time to move on, and cited tight bus regulations as a reason for selling assets to Buslink Sunraysia. 
"It's a complicated thing, operating buses," Mr Williams said. 
"There's an awful lot of regulatory stuff involved in safety, both for the passengers and also making sure that the buses are roadworthy. 
"We've done everything correctly over the years but it becomes a very complicated thing and I think a larger group have got better resources to look after that. 
"Both the directors, myself and Brian Coucill, are fairly old and we thought it's about time to hand on. 
"You can't go on forever. I'd just like some spare time ... so that myself and my wife can enjoy our retirement." Photo: Buslink, which will take over from Murton's, plans to bring new buses and services to Broken Hill. (Murton's Citybus) 
Mr Williams said he was confident far west residents would be in good hands under Buslink when it took over from December 31. 
"They're keeping all the staff, and doing the things the way we want to do it, except with a bit more resources than we would have had," Mr Williams said. 
Buslink also has some ideas of its own, including procuring a few new buses and settling in at a new bus depot. 
Managing director Sam Lucas said Buslink was also looking at expanding services and routes. 
"Clearly the two obvious ones will be [between] Adelaide and Broken Hill and Mildura [and] Broken Hill," Mr Lucas said. 
"Whether we do those separately or together or how that might look, that is something we'll definitely be having a look at."
